awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Impact of Cytoskeletal Dynamics on the Mechanical Behaviors of Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
Cells actively change their shape during essential life processes, from cell division to migration.  Their ability to do so depends upon their mechanical properties and their ability to generate mechanical forces, which are mediated by the internal scaffolding of the cell (cytoskeleton).  Far from a static structure, the cytoskeleton is highly dynamic, as it is constantly assembled and disassembled, yet maintains the shape of the cell continuously.  Without precedent in modern engineering, little is known regarding how the internal dynamics of assembly and disassembly within this material impacts the mechanical properties of the material itself.  Nor is it understood how cells use this relationship to generate forces and change its shape, as occurs throughout its lifetime.  To explore these relationships, the research team will engineer simplified, non-living versions of cells where the internal dynamics of the cytoskeleton can be controlled precisely and its impact on mechanics and "cell" shape can be measured quantitatively.  In parallel, they will use computational simulation to uncover how the modulation of internal dynamics manifests in mechanical changes of the cytoskeleton, providing insight into the development of new biologically-inspired materials.

The F-actin cytoskeleton provides the structural and mechanical support that maintains cell shape and mediates force production during essential life processes including cell division and migration.  The F-actin cytoskeleton is also highly dynamic, constantly assembling and disassembling, renewing itself in minutes.  However, how the renewal of the F-actin cytoskeleton (turnover) impacts the time-dependent mechanical properties of the cell, and its capacity to generate mechanical forces is uncertain.  Also uncertain, is how these mechanical changes in the F-actin cytoskeleton regulate the dynamics of cell shape change.   Connecting the dynamics of F-actin turnover to the mechanical behaviors of the cell has been difficult because the biochemical factors that control turnover are regulated internally through complex and overlapping pathways.  To reduce this complexity, the research team plans to reproduce shape changes within simplified, biomimetic cells in vitro, engineered from purified proteins and lipids, whose biochemical composition is controlled precisely.  With this "bottom-up" approach, the complicating influence of biochemical and genetic regulation by living cells is eliminated, facilitating the determination of a quantitative relationship between F-actin turnover, and the resultant mechanical and morphological changes in the "cell".  In parallel, they plan to conduct computational simulations to determine the molecular mechanisms by which the kinetics of F-actin turnover influence cytoskeletal mechanics, force production, and the experimentally observed changes in cell shape.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Living cells are inherently mechanical because they require the generation of mechanical forces for their physiological functions. The ability of cells to generate a force is attributed primarily to a complex, non-equilibrium biopolymer network called the actin cytoskeleton. Myosin II motor proteins walk on actin filaments (F-actins) toward the barbed end, which results in contraction of anti-parallel pairs of F-actins. This actomyosin contractility is a fundamental engine for force generation in both muscle and non-muscle cells. While the mechanism of force generation in muscle cells is understood relatively well, it still remains elusive how force generation is controlled within the actin cytoskeleton of the non-muscle cells. Unlike muscle cells, the actin cytoskeleton of non-muscle cells is highly disordered in terms of the polarity, orientation, and length of F-actin. It is also a very dynamic structure exhibiting continuous redistribution of F-actin, motors, actin cross-linking proteins (ACPs), and their diverse regulating proteins. F-actins in the cortex beneath the cell membrane consistently undergo rapid turnover via various actin dynamics facilitated by dozens of actin binding proteins. In this project, we aim to define how rapid in vivo actin turnover affects the contractile behaviors of the actin cytoskeleton.

As groundwork (W. Jung et al., Comput Part Mech, 2015), we studied the contraction and force generation of an actomyosin network without F-actin dynamics. We quantitatively determined effects of motor activity and the density and kinetics of ACPs on the accumulation and maintenance of mechanical tension within a disordered actomyosin network. We found that motors accumulate large stress quickly although this stress is relaxed over time unless there are sufficient ACPs to stabilize the network. Stabilization via ACPs helps motors to generate forces up to their maximum potential, leading to significant enhancement of the stability of stress generation.

In the second study (J. Li et al., Soft Matter, 2017), we incorporated F-actin severing with our network model. We demonstrated that networks may show the largest contraction at intermediate bending rigidity, not at the lowest rigidity, if filaments are severed by buckling arising from myosin activity; if filaments are very flexible, frequent severing events can severely deteriorate network connectivity, leading to the formation of multiple small foci and low network contraction. By contrast, if filaments are too stiff, the networks exhibit minimal contraction due to the inhibition of filament buckling. This study revealed that buckling-induced filament severing can modulate the contraction of active cytoskeletal networks, which has been neglected to date.

In the third study (T.C. Bidone et al., PLOS Comput Biol, 2017), we considered F-actin turnover by incorporating F-actin treadmilling with the network model. Structural reorganization of a network into a bundle facilitated by actomyosin contractility is a physiologically relevant and biophysically interesting process. Using the combined model, we demonstrated how the interplay between the density of myosin motors and cross-linking proteins and the rigidity, initial orientation, and F-actin turnover regulates the morphological transformation of a cross-linked actomyosin network into a bundle and the buildup of tension occurring during the transformation.

In an ongoing study, we reproduced the pulsed contraction only with the mechanical and dynamic behaviors of cytoskeletal elements. We found that pulsed clusters with physiologically relevant size and duration can appear only with both F-actin turnover and F-actin severing resulting from buckling induced by motor activities. We showed how parameters governing F-actin severing events regulate the size and duration of pulsed clusters. This study sheds light on underestimated significance of F-actin severing for the pulsed contraction observed in physiological processes.

In sum, we provided insights into understanding of the actomyosin contractility under physiologically relevant conditions in the four studies, which significant benefits various fields including biology, biophysics, and mechanobiology..

 


Last Modified: 10/01/2018
Modified by: Taeyoon Kim
